title: Linkage
text: TCGA Breast Cancer cohort dataset contains chromatin accessibility gene expression data  72 patients breast cancer. chromatin accessibility data normalized bulk ATAC-seq count matrix, prior count 5 added raw counts, put “counts per million”, log2 transformed, quantile normalized.  gene expression data normalized bulk RNA-seq count matrix, log2(fpkm+1) transformed. GSE121589 dataset contains chromatin accessibility gene expression data  33 mice Muscle Stem Cells (MuSCs). chromatin accessibility data normalized bulk ATAC-seq count matrix, prior count 5 added raw counts, put “counts per million”, log2 transformed, quantile normalized.  gene expression data normalized bulk RNA-seq count matrix, log2(fpkm+1) transformed. Two tab-delimited text/csv input files (chromatin accessibility matrix gene expression matrix) required running Linkage. gene expression matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix, first column represents gene symbols following columns represent normalized raw expression levels genes sample. chromatin accessibility matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix well, first three columns represent chromosome name, start coordinate chromosome end coordinate chromosome peaks respectively; remaining columns chromatin accessibility matrix file represent normalized raw chromatin accessibility levels peaks sample.  element  ready--analysis files appear Chromatin Accessibility Matrix panel Gene Expression Matrix panel.

title: Linkage
text: Regulatory Peaks Search Module allows users detect potential regulatory DNA regions specific genes. given input gene targeting DNA regions, Linkage automatically perform canonical correlation analysis quantitative chromatin accessibility measure region quantitative expression level gene across samples. Users can easily adjust region interest customize correlation algorithm (Spearman / Pearson / Kendall). ,  statistically significant results  listed  Potential Cis-regulatory Regions panel.  clicking  specific region panel, users can view scatter plot quantitative chromatin accessibility gene expression Correlation Plot panel. rho FDR correlation analysis also shown scatter plot.

title: Linkage
text: Regulatory Peaks Visualization Module allows users visualize coverage mapped ATAC-seq reads around given specific regulatory peak, well corresponding quantitative expression target gene regulatory peak. Users initially select regulatory peak obtained Regulatory Peaks Detection Module. Linkage categorizes samples five groups based quantitative chromatin accessibility  specific regulatory peak, ranging low high individual sample. coverage track mapped ATAC-seq reads boxplot target gene group shown simultaneously.

title: Linkage
text: Regulatory Peaks Annotation Module allows users visualize annotation predicational regulatory peaks Linkage. users click ‘Annotate Regulatory Peaks’, Linkage perform annotation  predicational regulatory peaks terms genomic location features, includes whether peak TSS, Exon, 5’ UTR, 3’ UTR, Intronic Intergenic  position strand information nearest gene peaks. effectively visualize overlaps distribution annotation peaks, Linkage also produces upsetplot adopting ChIPseeker package.

title: Linkage
text: Motif Analysis Module supports users visualize enriched transcription factor motifs within potential regulatory peaks. clicking  specific peak, users can view location binding score information enriched transcription factor region. users select one transcription factors, corresponding sequence logo cis-regulatory element appear Sequence-logo Plot panel.

title: Linkage
text: Regulatory Network Module helps users  visualize GRNs  nodes genes corresponding cis-regulatory elements，inferred previous analysis Linkage. First, users can input list interested genes  upload  gene-list file obtained previous analysis.  users can adjust series parameters related building GRN, including types  gene symbols, calculation methods thresholds  interactions nodes (edges GRNs). users click ‘Build Network’, Linkage perform canonical correlation analysis quantitative expression level  interested gene  potential cis-regulatory elements. significant calculation results  correlation analysis  shown  Gene-TF Table panel. Meanwhile, Linkage produces corresponding informatic interactive GRN adopting visNetwork package. Users can easily change network layouts, select subnetworks, save GRN spreadsheets interaction score plots.

title: Linkage
text: Pathway Enrichment Module supports users visualize tabular graphical pathway enrichment results interested gene lists, can produced previous analysis Linkage.  enrichment analysis can link gene lists underlying molecular pathways functional categories gene ontology (GO) Kyoto Encyclopedia Genes Genomes (KEGG).

title: linkage in Rstudio
text: chromatin accessibility data normalized bulk ATAC-seq count matrix, prior count 5 added raw counts, put “counts per million”, log2 transformed, quantile normalized.  gene expression data normalized bulk RNA-seq count matrix, log2(fpkm+1) transformed. Two tab-delimited text/csv input files (chromatin accessibility matrix gene expression matrix) required running Linkage. gene expression matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix, first column represents gene symbols following columns represent normalized raw expression levels genes sample. chromatin accessibility matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix well, first three columns represent chromosome name, start coordinate chromosome end coordinate chromosome peaks respectively; remaining columns chromatin accessibility matrix file represent normalized raw chromatin accessibility levels peaks sample.  element  ready--analysis files appear Chromatin Accessibility Matrix panel Gene Expression Matrix panel.
code: library(linkage) library(LinkageData) ATAC.seq <- BreastCancerATAC() RNA.seq <- BreastCancerRNA() LinkageObject <-   CreateLinkageObject(     ATAC_count = ATAC.seq,     RNA_count = RNA.seq,     Species = "Homo",     id_type = "ensembl_gene_id"   ) LinkageObject ## An LinkageObject  ## 59161 gene 215920 peak  ## Active gene: 0  ## Active peak: positive peak 0 negetive peak 0  ## Active TF: 0

title: linkage in Rstudio
text: Regulatory Peaks Search allows users detect potential regulatory DNA regions specific genes. given input gene targeting DNA regions, Linkage automatically perform canonical correlation analysis quantitative chromatin accessibility measure region quantitative expression level gene across samples. Users can easily adjust region interest customize correlation algorithm (Spearman / Pearson / Kendall). ,  statistically significant results  listed  Potential Cis-regulatory Regions panel.  clicking  specific region panel, users can view scatter plot quantitative chromatin accessibility gene expression Correlation Plot panel. rho FDR correlation analysis also shown scatter plot.
code: gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name"   ) CorrPlot(LinkageObject, gene = "TSPAN6")

title: linkage in Rstudio
text: Regulatory Peaks Visualization allows users visualize coverage mapped ATAC-seq reads around given specific regulatory peak, well corresponding quantitative expression target gene regulatory peak. Users initially select regulatory peak obtained Regulatory Peaks Detection Module. Linkage categorizes samples five groups based quantitative chromatin accessibility  specific regulatory peak, ranging low high individual sample. coverage track mapped ATAC-seq reads boxplot target gene group shown simultaneously.

title: linkage in Rstudio
text: Regulatory Peaks Annotation allows users visualize annotation predicational regulatory peaks Linkage.Linkage perform annotation  predicational regulatory peaks terms genomic location features, includes whether peak TSS, Exon, 5’ UTR, 3’ UTR, Intronic Intergenic  position strand information nearest gene peaks. effectively visualize overlaps distribution annotation peaks, Linkage also produces upsetplot adopting ChIPseeker package.

title: linkage in Rstudio
text: Regulatory Network helps users  visualize GRNs  nodes genes corresponding cis-regulatory elements，inferred previous analysis Linkage. First, users can input list interested genes  upload  gene-list file obtained previous analysis.  users can adjust series parameters related building GRN, including types  gene symbols, calculation methods thresholds  interactions nodes (edges GRNs). Linkage perform canonical correlation analysis quantitative expression level  interested gene  potential cis-regulatory elements. significant calculation results  correlation analysis  shown  Gene-TF Table panel. Meanwhile, Linkage produces corresponding informatic interactive GRN adopting visNetwork package. Users can easily change network layouts, select subnetworks, save GRN spreadsheets interaction score plots.
code: LinkageObject <-   MultipleMotifAnalysis(LinkageObject = LinkageObject,                         Species = "Homo",                         TF_cor_method = "pearson") LinkageObject <-   CreateNetworkObject(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     genelist_idtype = "entrezgene_id",     filter_col = "FDR",     filter_value = 0.01   ) BuildNetwork(LinkageObject)

title: Monogenic MOTIF analysis
text: chromatin accessibility data normalized bulk ATAC-seq count matrix, prior count 5 added raw counts, put “counts per million”, log2 transformed, quantile normalized.  gene expression data normalized bulk RNA-seq count matrix, log2(fpkm+1) transformed. Two tab-delimited text/csv input files (chromatin accessibility matrix gene expression matrix) required running Linkage. gene expression matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix, first column represents gene symbols following columns represent normalized raw expression levels genes sample. chromatin accessibility matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix well, first three columns represent chromosome name, start coordinate chromosome end coordinate chromosome peaks respectively; remaining columns chromatin accessibility matrix file represent normalized raw chromatin accessibility levels peaks sample.  element  ready--analysis files appear Chromatin Accessibility Matrix panel Gene Expression Matrix panel.
code: library(linkage) library(LinkageData) ATAC.seq <- BreastCancerATAC() RNA.seq <- BreastCancerRNA() LinkageObject <-   CreateLinkageObject(     ATAC_count = ATAC.seq,     RNA_count = RNA.seq,     Species = "Homo",     id_type = "ensembl_gene_id"   ) LinkageObject ## An LinkageObject  ## 59161 gene 215920 peak  ## Active gene: 0  ## Active peak: positive peak 0 negetive peak 0  ## Active TF: 0

title: Monogenic MOTIF analysis
text: Regulatory Peaks Search allows users detect potential regulatory DNA regions specific genes. given input gene targeting DNA regions, Linkage automatically perform canonical correlation analysis quantitative chromatin accessibility measure region quantitative expression level gene across samples. Users can easily adjust region interest customize correlation algorithm (Spearman / Pearson / Kendall). ,  statistically significant results  listed  Potential Cis-regulatory Regions panel.  clicking  specific region panel, users can view scatter plot quantitative chromatin accessibility gene expression Correlation Plot panel. rho FDR correlation analysis also shown scatter plot.
code: gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name"   )

title: Monogenic MOTIF analysis
text: Motif Analysis Module supports users visualize enriched transcription factor motifs within potential regulatory peaks. clicking specific peak, users can view location binding score information enriched transcription factor region. users select one transcription factors, corresponding sequence logo cis-regulatory element appear Sequence-logo Plot panel.
code: library(DT) df <- SingleMotifAnalysis(LinkageObject@cor.peak$TSPAN6, "Homo") brks1 <-   quantile(df$score,            probs = seq(.05, .95, .05),            na.rm = TRUE) DT::datatable(   df,   selection = "single",   extensions = c("Scroller", "RowReorder"),   option = list(     rowReorder = TRUE,     deferRender = TRUE,     scrollY = 295,     scroller = TRUE,     scrollX = TRUE,     searchHighlight = TRUE,     orderClasses = TRUE,     autoWidth = F   ) ) %>% formatStyle(   names(df)[8],   background = styleColorBar(range(brks1), 'lightblue'),   backgroundSize = '90% 100%',   backgroundRepeat = 'no-repeat',   backgroundPosition = 'center' ) SeqLogoPlot("MA0618.1")

title: TCGA-BRCA guided tutorial
text: tutorial, analyzing dataset Breast Cancer (BRCA) freely available TCGA.  dataset contains chromatin accessibility gene expression data  72 patients BRCA, can load LinkageData. can also found raw data . start loading data.  BreastCancerATAC()  BreastCancerRNA() function can load return available chromatin accessibility gene expression matrices Linkage. chromatin accessibility matrix normalized bulk ATAC-seq count matrix, prior count 5 added raw counts, put "counts per million", log2 transformed, quantile normalized. gene expression matrix normalized bulk RNA-seq count matrix, log2(fpkm+1) transformed. next use chromatin accessibility gene expression matrix create Linkage object. object serves container contains data (like count matrix) analysis (like regulatory peaks, active TFBS).
code: library(linkage) library(LinkageData) ATAC.seq <- BreastCancerATAC() RNA.seq <- BreastCancerRNA() LinkageObject <-   CreateLinkageObject(     ATAC_count = ATAC.seq,     RNA_count = RNA.seq,     Species = "Homo",     id_type = "ensembl_gene_id"   ) LinkageObject ## An LinkageObject  ## 59161 gene 215920 peak  ## Active gene: 0  ## Active peak: positive peak 0 negetive peak 0  ## Active TF: 0

title: TCGA-BRCA guided tutorial
text: Linkage allows search potential regulatory peaks given genes within specified region. example , detect potential regulatory peaks  three different genes (“TSPAN6”, “CD99”, “KLHL13”) within range 500000 bp around . plot top 6 significant results (sort FDR).
code: gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name"   ) CorrPlot(LinkageObject, gene = "TSPAN6")

title: TCGA-BRCA guided tutorial
text: Now can plot  Tn5 integration frequency  gene expression level across regions genome using TrackPlot() function. easier visualization, Linkage categorizes samples five groups based quantitative chromatin accessibility specific regulatory peak low high. group, pseudo-bulk accessibility tracks expression boxplot target gene can viewed. Alongside accessibility tracks can visualize important information including gene annotation peak coordinates.

title: TCGA-BRCA guided tutorial
text: Linkage can help visualize annotation predicational regulatory peaks. PeakAnnotation() perform annotation predicational regulatory peaks terms genomic location features, includes whether peak TSS, Exon, 5' UTR, 3' UTR, Intronic Intergenic position strand information nearest gene peaks. can produce upsetplot visualizing overlaps distribution annotation peaks AnnoUpsetPlot() function.

title: TCGA-BRCA guided tutorial
text: Next, can visualize enriched CREs within potential regulatory peaks MotifEnrichment() function. CREs TFs binding play central role gene transcription regulation, can detected ATAC-seq data. function can help view location binding score information enriched TFBS given DNA region. SeqLogoPlot() function help get sequence logo given transcription factors.
code: library(DT) df <- MotifEnrichment(LinkageObject@cor.peak$TSPAN6, "Homo") brks1 <-   quantile(df$score,            probs = seq(.05, .95, .05),            na.rm = TRUE) DT::datatable(   df,   selection = "single",   extensions = c("Scroller", "RowReorder"),   option = list(     rowReorder = TRUE,     deferRender = TRUE,     scrollY = 295,     scroller = TRUE,     scrollX = TRUE,     searchHighlight = TRUE,     orderClasses = TRUE,     autoWidth = F   ) ) %>% formatStyle(   names(df)[8],   background = styleColorBar(range(brks1), 'lightblue'),   backgroundSize = '90% 100%',   backgroundRepeat = 'no-repeat',   backgroundPosition = 'center' ) SeqLogoPlot("MA0618.1")

title: TCGA-BRCA guided tutorial
text: tutorial, analyzing dataset Breast Cancer (BRCA) freely available TCGA.  dataset contains chromatin accessibility gene expression data  72 patients BRCA, can load LinkageData. can also found raw data . start loading data.  BreastCancerATAC()  BreastCancerRNA() function can load return available chromatin accessibility gene expression matrices Linkage. chromatin accessibility matrix normalized bulk ATAC-seq count matrix, prior count 5 added raw counts, put "counts per million", log2 transformed, quantile normalized. gene expression matrix normalized bulk RNA-seq count matrix, log2(fpkm+1) transformed. next use chromatin accessibility gene expression matrix create Linkage object. object serves container contains data (like count matrix) analysis (like regulatory peaks, active TFBS).
code: library(Linkage) # library(LinkageData) # ATAC_count <- BreastCancerATAC() # RNA_count <- BreastCancerRNA() LinkageObject <-   CreateLinkageObject(     ATAC_count = Small_ATAC,     RNA_count = Small_RNA,     Species = "Homo",     id_type = "ensembl_gene_id"   ) LinkageObject ## An LinkageObject  ## 48 gene 32 peak  ## Active gene: 0  ## Active peak: positive peak 0 negetive peak 0  ## Active TF: 0

title: TCGA-BRCA guided tutorial
text: Linkage allows search potential regulatory peaks given genes within specified region. example , detect potential regulatory peaks  three different genes (“TSPAN6”, “CD99”, “KLHL13”) within range 500000 bp around . plot top 6 significant results (sort FDR).
code: gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name",   ) CorrPlot(LinkageObject, gene = "CD99")

Alongside accessibility tracks can visualize important information including gene annotation peak coordinates.

title: AnnoUpsetPlot — AnnoUpsetPlot
text: LinkageObject LinkageObject annottation. order_by intersections matrix ordered . Options include frequency (entered "freq"), degree, order.

title: AnnoUpsetPlot — AnnoUpsetPlot
code: library(Linkage) data("SmallLinkageObject") gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = SmallLinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name"   ) peakAnno <- PeakAnnotation(LinkageObject, Species = "Homo") #> Loading required package: org.Hs.eg.db #> Loading required package: AnnotationDbi #> Loading required package: stats4 #> Loading required package: BiocGenerics #>  #> Attaching package: 'BiocGenerics' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     IQR, mad, sd, var, xtabs #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     Filter, Find, Map, Position, Reduce, anyDuplicated, aperm, append, #>     as.data.frame, basename, cbind, colnames, dirname, do.call, #>     duplicated, eval, evalq, get, grep, grepl, intersect, is.unsorted, #>     lapply, mapply, match, mget, order, paste, pmax, pmax.int, pmin, #>     pmin.int, rank, rbind, rownames, sapply, setdiff, sort, table, #>     tapply, union, unique, unsplit, which.max, which.min #> Loading required package: Biobase #> Welcome to Bioconductor #>  #>     Vignettes contain introductory material; view with #>     'browseVignettes()'. To cite Bioconductor, see #>     'citation("Biobase")', and for packages 'citation("pkgname")'. #> Loading required package: IRanges #> Loading required package: S4Vectors #>  #> Attaching package: 'S4Vectors' #> The following object is masked from 'package:utils': #>  #>     findMatches #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     I, expand.grid, unname #>  #> Attaching package: 'IRanges' #> The following object is masked from 'package:grDevices': #>  #>     windows #>  #> 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns #> 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns #> 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns AnnoUpsetPlot(LinkageObject = peakAnno) #> Warning: `cols` is now required when using `unnest()`. #> ℹ Please use `cols = c(res)`.

title: MotifAnalysis. — BuildGRNs
text: LinkageObject Linkage Object RegulatoryPeak. Species Select species, Homo Mus.default Homo. TF_cor_method correlation calculation, pearson/spearman/kendall can selected.

title: MotifAnalysis. — BuildGRNs
code: library(Linkage) LinkageObject <-   CreateLinkageObject(     ATAC_count = Small_ATAC,     RNA_count = Small_RNA,     Species = "Homo",     id_type = "ensembl_gene_id"   ) gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name"   ) LinkageObject <-   BuildGRNs(LinkageObject = LinkageObject,                         Species = "Homo",                         TF_cor_method = "pearson") #>  #> Attaching package: 'Biostrings' #> The following object is masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     strsplit #>  #> Attaching package: 'rtracklayer' #> The following object is masked from 'package:BiocIO': #>  #>     FileForFormat

Correlation scatter plot. — CorrPlot
text: LinkageObject Linkage Object. gene gene want visualized. color color straight line. fill color fill.

title: Correlation scatter plot. — CorrPlot
code: library(Linkage) data("SmallLinkageObject") gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = SmallLinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name"   ) CorrPlot(LinkageObject, gene = "TSPAN6") #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' #> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Create a Linkage Object — CreateLinkageObject
text: ATAC_count chromatin accessibility matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix well, first three columns represent chromosome name, start coordinate chromosome end coordinate chromosome peaks respectively; remaining columns chromatin accessibility matrix file represent normalized raw chromatin accessibility levels peaks sample. RNA_count gene expression matrix file tab-delimited multi-column data matrix, first column represents gene symbols following columns represent normalized raw expression levels genes sample. Species Select species, Homo Mus. id_type RNA_count gene id type. ensembl_gene_id, external_gene_name, entrezgene_id types genetic IDs choose .

title: Create a Linkage Object — CreateLinkageObject
code: library(Linkage) LinkageObject <-   CreateLinkageObject(     ATAC_count = Small_ATAC,     RNA_count = Small_RNA,     Species = "Homo",     id_type = "ensembl_gene_id"   )

title: Create Network Object. — CreateNetworkObject
text: LinkageObject Linkage Object MultipleMotifAnalysis. genelist_idtype ensembl_gene_id, external_gene_name, entrezgene_id types genetic IDs choose . filter_col p_value,FDR,rho can selected. filter_value Cutoff value filter_col.

title: Create Network Object. — CreateNetworkObject
code: library(linkage) library(LinkageData) ATAC.seq <- BreastCancerATAC() RNA.seq <- BreastCancerRNA() LinkageObject <-   CreateLinkageObject(     ATAC_count = ATAC.seq,     RNA_count = RNA.seq,     Species = "Homo",     id_type = "ensembl_gene_id"   ) gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name"   ) LinkageObject <-   MultipleMotifAnalysis(LinkageObject = LinkageObject,                         Species = "Homo",                         TF_cor_method = "pearson") #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero LinkageObject <-   CreateNetworkObject(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     genelist_idtype = "entrezgene_id",     filter_col = "FDR",     filter_value = 0.01   )

title: Enrichment analysis Barplot — EnrichBarPlot
text: object Go KEGG object. size font size.

title: Enrichment analysis Barplot — EnrichBarPlot
code: library(Linkage) data("SASPGeneSet") go <-   GOEnrichment(gene_list = SASPGeneSet,                Species = "Homo",                genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name") p <- EnrichBarPlot(go) #> Scale for y is already present. #> Adding another scale for y, which will replace the existing scale.

title: Enrichment analysis Cnetplot — EnrichCnetPlot
code: library(Linkage) data("SASPGeneSet") go <-   GOEnrichment(gene_list = SASPGeneSet,                Species = "Homo",                genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name") p <- EnrichCnetPlot(go)

title: Enrichment analysis Dotplot — EnrichDotPlot

code: library(Linkage) data("SASPGeneSet") go <-   GOEnrichment(gene_list = SASPGeneSet,                Species = "Homo",                genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name") p <- EnrichDotPlot(go) #> Scale for y is already present. #> Adding another scale for y, which will replace the existing scale.

title: Enrichment analysis Upsetplot — EnrichUpsetPlot
code: library(Linkage) data("SASPGeneSet") go <-   GOEnrichment(gene_list = SASPGeneSet,                Species = "Homo",                genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name") p <- EnrichUpsetPlot(go)

title: Enrichment analysis Wordcloud — EnrichWordCloud
text: object Go KEGG object. Type Indicate whether GO KEGG object, GO KEGG can selected. plotly logical value,Whether use plotly.default TRUE.

title: Enrichment analysis Wordcloud — EnrichWordCloud
code: library(Linkage) data("SASPGeneSet") go <-   GOEnrichment(gene_list = SASPGeneSet,                Species = "Homo",                genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name") p <- EnrichWordCloud(go, Type = "GO")

title: Create Network Object. — FilterGRNs
text: LinkageObject Linkage Object BuildGRNs. genelist_idtype ensembl_gene_id, external_gene_name, entrezgene_id types genetic IDs choose . filter_col p_value,FDR,rho can selected. filter_value Cutoff value filter_col.

title: Create Network Object. — FilterGRNs
code: library(Linkage) data("Small_ATAC.rda") #> Warning: data set 'Small_ATAC.rda' not found data("Small_RNA.rda") #> Warning: data set 'Small_RNA.rda' not found LinkageObject <-   CreateLinkageObject(     ATAC_count = Small_ATAC,     RNA_count = Small_RNA,     Species = "Homo",     id_type = "ensembl_gene_id"   ) gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name"   ) LinkageObject <-   BuildGRNs(LinkageObject = LinkageObject,                         Species = "Homo",                         TF_cor_method = "pearson") LinkageObject <-   FilterGRNs(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     genelist_idtype = "entrezgene_id",     filter_col = "FDR",     filter_value = 0.01   )

title: GO enrichment analysis — GOEnrichment

title: MotifAnalysis. — MultipleMotifAnalysis
code: library(linkage) library(LinkageData) ATAC.seq <- BreastCancerATAC() RNA.seq <- BreastCancerRNA() LinkageObject <-   CreateLinkageObject(     ATAC_count = ATAC.seq,     RNA_count = RNA.seq,     Species = "Homo",     id_type = "ensembl_gene_id"   ) gene_list <- c("TSPAN6", "CD99", "KLHL13") LinkageObject <-   RegulatoryPeak(     LinkageObject = LinkageObject,     gene_list = gene_list,     genelist_idtype = "external_gene_name"   ) LinkageObject <-   MultipleMotifAnalysis(LinkageObject = LinkageObject,                         Species = "Homo",                         TF_cor_method = "pearson") #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero #> Warning: the standard deviation is zero
